articleTitle: Intel to lay off more than 15% of its workforce as it cuts costs to try to turn its business around
articleDescription: Chipmaker Intel says it is cutting 15% of its massive workforce — about 15,000 jobs — as it tries to turn its business around to compete with more successful rivals like Nvidia and AMD. The Santa Clara, California-based company said Thursday it is also suspen…
articleContent:
Chipmaker Intel says it is cutting 15% of its huge workforce about 15,000 jobs as it tries to turn its business around to compete with more successful rivals like Nvidia and AMD.
In a memo to staff,… [+4460 chars]
fqTitle: Will Intel lay off more than 15% of its workforce by August 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if Intel announces and proceeds with laying off more than 15% of its workforce by August 31, 2024. The layoffs must be explicitly confirmed by Intel through official statements or reports from at least two reputable news organizations such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post.

The suspension must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post.

articleContent:
ATLANTA (AP) Former President Jimmy Carter will be honored next month, ahead of his 100th birthday, with a musical gala at the Fox Theatre in Atlanta, The Carter Center announced Thursday. 
The Sept… [+1834 chars]

fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if a musical gala celebrating Jimmy Carter's 100th birthday is held at Atlanta's Fox Theatre by August 2024. The event must be publicly reported as taking place at the specified location and for the specified purpose.

articleTitle: Simone Biles edges Brazil's Rebeca Andrade for her second Olympic all-around gymnastics title
articleDescription: Simone Biles edged Rebeca Andrade of Brazil during a tense all-around gymnastics final Thursday to become a two-time Olympic champion. Biles’ total of 59.131 was just ahead of Andrade at 57.932. That's one of the closest calls Biles has ever…
articleContent:
PARIS (AP) Simone Biles remains peerless. Even when she's not quite perfect.
The American gymnastics star edged Brazil's Rebeca Andrade during a tense Olympic all-around final Thursday. Biles' total… [+4511 chars]
fqTitle: Will Simone Biles win another Olympic all-around gymnastics title by August, 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if Simone Biles wins another Olympic all-around gymnastics title by August 31, 2024. An Olympic all-around gymnastics title refers to the individual all-around competition in gymnastics at the Olympics.

articleTitle: India offers $300 million loan to build up Vietnam's maritime security, saying it is a key partner
articleDescription: India has offered Vietnam a $300 million loan to build up the Southeast Asian country's maritime security, as the two sides say they want to double their trade and investment within five years. Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday told visiting Vietnamese…
articleContent:
NEW DELHI (AP) India on Thursday offered a $300 million loan to build up Vietnams maritime security, as the two sides said they want to double their trade and investment within five years.
Prime Min… [+1925 chars]
fqTitle: Will Vietnam accept a $300 million loan from India for maritime security by August, 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if Vietnam officially accepts a $300 million loan from India specifically for maritime security by August 31, 2024. Official acceptance must be confirmed through an official statement from the Vietnamese government or a reputable news source.

articleTitle: Inmate sentenced to more than 4 years in prison killing of Boston gangster James ‘Whitey’ Bulger

fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if Paul J. DeCologero files an appeal against his sentence for his role in the killing of James 'Whitey' Bulger by August 31, 2024. An appeal must be officially recorded in a court of law to count.

articleTitle: The number of Americans filing for jobless claims hits highest level in a year
articleDescription: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits jumped to its highest level in a year last week, even as the labor market remains broadly healthy. Jobless claims for the week ending July 27 climbed by 14,000 to249,000 from 235,000 the previous week, …
articleContent:
The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits jumped to its highest level in a year last week, even as the labor market remains surprisingly healthy in an era of high interest rates.
Jobl… [+2061 chars]
fqTitle: Will the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits exceed 250,000 in any week by August, 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits in any week exceeds 250,000 by August 31, 2024. The data must be reported by an official source such as the U.S. Department of Labor.

articleTitle: Proposed rule would ban airlines from charging parents to sit with their children

articleContent:
The U.S. Department of Transportation is proposing a new rule that would ban airlines from charging parents more to sit with their young children.
Under the proposal, released Thursday, U.S. and for… [+2672 chars]
fqTitle: Will a proposed rule by the U.S. Department of Transportation ban airlines from charging parents to sit with their children by August 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a proposed rule by the U.S. Department of Transportation is implemented that bans airlines from charging parents to sit with their children aged 13 or younger. The rule must be officially adopted and enforceable by this date.

fqTitle: Will U.S. airlines be required to seat children 13 or younger with their parents without extra charges by August 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, U.S. airlines are required by regulation to seat children aged 13 or younger with their parents without any additional charges. The requirement must be legally binding and in effect by this date.

articleTitle: US road safety agency will look into fatal crash near Seattle involving Tesla using automated system
articleDescription: U.S. road safety investigators say they will look into an April crash near Seattle after authorities determined that a Tesla was operating on the company’s “Full Self-Driving” system when it hit and killed a motorcyclist. The National Highway Traffic Safety A…
articleContent: DETROIT (AP) U.S. road safety investigators say they will look into an April crash near Seattle after authorities determined that a Tesla was operating on the companys Full Self-Driving system when i… [+1955 chars]
fqTitle: Will the U.S. road safety investigation find fault with Tesla's Full Self-Driving system by August, 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the U.S. road safety investigation concludes that Tesla's Full Self-Driving system was at fault in the fatal crash near Seattle involving a motorcyclist. The conclusion must be officially reported by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) or another authoritative body. If no such conclusion is reached or reported by the specified date, this question will resolve as NO.

fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, new federal regulations specifically targeting Tesla's Full Self-Driving system are enacted. This includes any new rules, restrictions, or requirements imposed by federal authorities such as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). If no new federal regulations are enacted by the specified date, this question will resolve as NO.

fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Tesla issues an official recall for vehicles equipped with the Full Self-Driving system. The recall must be publicly announced and documented by Tesla or a relevant regulatory authority such as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). If no such recall is issued by the specified date, this question will resolve as NO.

articleTitle: Black and other minority farmers are getting $2 billion from USDA after years of discrimination
articleDescription: Black and other minority farmers are set to receive more than $2 billion in federal aid in response to decades of discrimination by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. President Joe Biden announced the payments Wednesday. The USDA says more than 23,000 farmer…
articleContent: COLUMBIA, Mo. (AP) The Biden administration has doled out more than $2 billion in direct payments for Black and other minority farmers discriminated against by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the… [+3078 chars]
fqTitle: Will more than 23,000 farmers receive federal aid by August 2024?
fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if more than 23,000 farmers, including Black and other minority farmers, receive federal aid from the USDA by August 31, 2024. The aid must be part of the $2 billion package announced for addressing past discrimination.

articleTitle: Black and other minority farmers are getting $2 billion from USDA after years of discrimination

fqBody: This question will resolve as YES if the USDA distributes the entire $2 billion federal aid package to Black and other minority farmers by August 31, 2024. The aid is meant to address decades of discrimination.
